content.value: The government announced today (15 September 2011) that desoxypipradrol (2-DPMP), the active compound found in some legal highs branded â€˜Ivory Waveâ€™, and phenazepam are to be controlled under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971. 2-DPMP and its related compounds, D2PM and diphenylmethylpyrrolidine, will become class B drugs and phenazepam class C.

This means that once approved by parliament in 2012, the drugs will be illegal to have, give away or sell. Possession of either drug could result in a prison sentence and an unlimited fine. Supplying someone else, including your friends, could mean up 14 years in prison.The plan to ban the drugs follows a recommendation from an independent body of experts, the Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs (ACMD).
2-DPMP
Read more about 2-DPMP
Phenazepam

Phenazepam is currently being sold as a powder or as a liquid and marketed as a legal high such as â€˜Bonsaiâ€™ or â€˜Bonsai Supersleepâ€™ or as fake Valium. It has a sedative effect, relieving tension and anxiety, and making the user feel calm and relaxed.

Itâ€™s a powerful benzodiazepine (tranquiliser), approximately five times stronger than Valium, and so itâ€™s easy to take too much and overdose. Although it takes a couple of hours for the effects of phenazepam to kick in, it stays active for a long time after being taken. This means that there is a risk that people will re-dose before they feel the effects and increase their risk of overdosing.Â
Read more about phenazepam
.Updated on 21 November 2011

title.en-US: Cocaine: what you need to know

content.value: Cocaineâ€™s been in the news again this week, but whatâ€™s the big deal about coke?
Taking cocaine is associated with good times â€“ feeling confident, talking funny nonsense with your mates and making your nights out last longer.
But what about the bad times? Like when you are feeling paranoid, the next day comedown or the nights when all you can think about is your next line?

Cocaine can make you feel good, but itâ€™s very addictive and it can easily become a habit that controls your life. And itâ€™s not as safe as you may think it is â€“ repeated use can cause agitated behaviour, mood swings, and heart attacks.Itâ€™s also a Class A drug, which means itâ€™s illegal to have, give away or sell. If the police catch you with cocaine, theyâ€™ll always take some action. This could include a formal caution, arrest, and prosecution.

cocaine

content.value: On 9th May 2012 the Government announced their intention to create a new drug driving offence, which will make it much easier for the police to take action against drug drivers.Under these new proposals it will be an offence to drive a motor vehicle if you have specified controlled drugs in excess of specified limits in your body.

The Department for Transport estimates that approximately 140 of all road deaths in 2010 were related to drug impaired driving. An independent review of drink and drug driving law in 2010 recommended that a new offence should be developed.
How will the law change?

The new offence is set out in the Crime and Courts Bill. If the Bill becomes law it will be illegal to drive or be in charge of a motor vehicle with specified controlled drugs in your bloodstream over the limit set for each drug.The exact drugs and limits covered by the offence will be set following advice from an expert panel and a public consultation.Devices for police officers to use at the roadside to screen for drugs in the body are expected to receive approval by the end of the year. The penalty for the new offence will be maximum of 6 months imprisonment and / or up to Â£5,000 fine, and an automatic driving ban of at least 12 months.
What is the current law?

It is already an offence to drive whilst impaired by drugs. This covers both illegal and legal/prescription drugs. If your driving has been negatively affected by the drugs you have taken, you can get a heavy fine, be disqualified from driving or even go to prison. This will remain in place alongside the new drug drive offence.

content.value: The drug alprazolam is often called Xanax, after one of the most common brand names. We know that using alprazolam has caused some young people to end up in hospital, particularly when they have mixed it with alcohol.
Alprazolam is an anti-anxiety medicine in theÂ
benzodiazepine family
Â and is similar to diazepam (Valium) but itâ€™s about 20 times stronger and has a quicker, shorter-acting effect. If you take alprazolam you might very quickly feel relaxed, tired and sleepy.

But you are also at risk of serious harm if you take alprazolam. Like other benzos, long-term use could mean you become physically dependent on it and then suffer withdrawal symptoms if you stop using it. Alprazolam can also cause blackouts and put you at greater risk of being taken advantage of sexually. If you mix it with alcohol youâ€™re at a big risk of overdose caused by heart and breathing problems â€“ and this can lead to death.
If you or someone you know gets into trouble with alprazolam, you will need to act quickly.Â
The Emergency Help page
Â gives you advice about what to do if itâ€™s an emergency. If itâ€™s not an emergency but you or a friend need help, you should searchÂ
FRANK to find support near you

content.value: The law on so-called legal highs changes on 26 May 2016. Thatâ€™s when the â€˜
New Psychoactive Substances Act

â€˜ comes into force, making it illegal to supply any â€˜legal highsâ€™ for human consumption. The changes in the law mean itâ€™s now an offence to sell or even give psychoactive substances to anyone for free, even to friends.
Police will take action where they find people committing these offences. Punishments range from a prohibition notice, which is a formal warning, to 7 years in prison.
The Act will also gives police and local authorities greater powers to tackle the trade in psychoactive substances, including stopping and searching people they think are supplying these drugs.

Until now, there has have been some psychoactive substances that have been legal, hence the name â€˜legal highsâ€™. However, this name wasnâ€™t helpful because there have been an increasing number of these drugs which have been made illegal in recent years after their harms were looked at.

Now that thereâ€™s a blanket ban on these substances, the term â€˜legal highsâ€™ isnâ€™t relevant anymore, so weâ€™ve changed the name of the FRANK legal highs page to new psychoactive substances, which is another widely-used term for these drugs.
The message about these drugs remains the same: you never know what you are getting; they can be incredibly harmful and sharing drugs with your friends means you are putting them at risk.

title.en-US: Drug Driving? Youâ€™re now more likely to be caught and convicted!

content.value: A new roadside test being used by the Police means if you drug drive youâ€™re more likely to be caught and since the new law introduced last year - youâ€™re also more likely to be convicted.
It is an offence toÂ
drive with certain drugs

Â above a specified level in your blood. Seventeen medicines and illegal drugs are covered by the law, including cannabis, cocaine, ecstasy and ketamine. The limits for all illegal drugs are extremely low.

Taking even a very small amount of an illegal drug could put you over the limit. The Police can now check how much youâ€™ve taken using a roadside drug screening device or test your ability to drive using aÂ
field impairment assessment.
A drug drive conviction will have a serious effect on your life including a criminal record and a minimum 12 month driving ban and either a heavy fine, 6 months prison sentence or both.

Â Donâ€™t take drugs and drive.If you want to talk to FRANK in confidence then you can call the helpline 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on 0300 123 6600 or you can chat online between 2-6pm every day.

content.value: â€˜Spiceâ€™ is a name used for a whole range of different drugs supposed to mimic the effects of cannabis. If you buy Spice there is no way to know which of these drugs you are getting and how dangerous it could be.
What is Spice?

Spice is usually a brand name for synthetic cannabinoids - chemicals that are made to act like the active part of cannabis, a substance called tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). As synthetic cannabinoids act like cannabis the effects - good and bad - are likely to be very similar to cannabis. Some users will feel happy and relaxed, may get the giggles, feel hunger pangs and become very talkative. Others may feel ill or paranoid.
Synthetic cannabinoids are usually sold in â€˜herbalâ€™ smoking mixtures. Sometimes these smoking mixtures have been found not to contain any synthetic cannibinoids at all!There are lots of different types of synthetic cannabinoids and a large number have become Class B drugs, which are illegal to have, give away or sell. You can never be sure what is in a smoking mixture so itâ€™s often hard to tell whether it is illegal or not. There is no way to know which and how much of these drugs you are getting and how dangerous it could be.Youâ€™ll find more information on Spice from the links or you canÂ
talk to FRANK on 0300 123 6600
Â in complete confidence.
How do I know what Iâ€™m taking?

The simple answer is that you donâ€™t. In fact, you can never be sure that any powder, pill or liquid contains what youâ€™re told it does.You can also not be sure how you might react to particular drugs. Everyone is different.
What do I do if I feel unwell?

If youâ€™ve taken something and you find you start to feel unwell, take time out to look after yourself and ask for help if you need it. If the problem doesnâ€™t improve or is getting worse, you should seek medical help.

There are lots of different types of synthetic cannabinoids and a large number have become Class B drugs, which are illegal to have, give away or sell. You can never be sure what is in a smoking mixture so itâ€™s often hard to tell whether it is illegal or not. content.value: There is a new drug drive law in England and Wales. The new law makes it illegal to drive with a specific controlled drug in the body above the accepted limit for that drug.
What does this all mean?
On March 2nd a new drug driving law came in to force in England and Wales
It is now illegal to drive with certain drugs above specified blood levels in the body
Limits are set at very low levels for eight illegal drugs such as cannabis and cocaine

Some medicines will also be included in the new law but if you are taking medicines as directed and your driving is not impaired, then you are not breaking the law. To find out more, ask your doctor or a member of the pharmacy team.

Remember, drugs impair your driving. If you are caught a drug drive conviction will have a serious effect on your life including a criminal record, a minimum 12 month driving ban and a fine of up to Â£5,000. It could also cost you your job.For more information about the new law,Â
click here

title.en-US: Myth busting: The top five booze fails

content.value:
Christmas is just around the corner, which means party season is about to kick off, but whatâ€™s the deal with all the drinking?
Thereâ€™s lots of information about alcohol out there which can get confusing. FRANK sets the record straight by busting some of the most common booze myths.
Myth:
Â Drinking makes you more confident and fun
Busted:
Â Drinking can make you dance like your dad

Lots of people think that drinking looks fun and will make them feel confident. But there are two sides to it â€“ drinking isnâ€™t all laughs. Although we donâ€™t always talk about it much, drinking can cause all kinds of problems. Although drinking alcohol can make you feel more confident, it can also make you do things you wish you hadnâ€™t - things that can get caught on camera.
Myth:
Â Donâ€™t eat carbs after 8pm
Busted:
Â Eat!
Donâ€™t drink on an empty stomach. Before you go out, have a meal that includes carbohydrates (such as pasta or rice) or fats. The food will help slow down the bodyâ€™s absorption of alcohol.
Myth:
Â A drink in the morning will cure a hangover
Busted:
Â Avoid the hairy dog!

Hangover cures like the â€˜hair of the dogâ€™ (drinking more alcohol in the morning) are generally a myth. There are no cures for a hangover. There are only tips for avoiding hangovers and for easing the symptoms if you have one. If you have a big night out, try to drink a glass of water between alcoholic drinks during the night and take a glass of water with you to bed and sip it through the night.
Myth:
Â My friends wonâ€™t like me if I donâ€™t drink with them
Busted:
Â Friends respect your honesty

It is ok not to drink and you should never feel pressurised into doing something you donâ€™t want to do. Remember your friends will respect you more for saying how you feel about drinking. Talking to your friends about the reasons you donâ€™t want to drink can help the situation and you may not be the only one who feels this way. Try arranging to meet them to do other things that donâ€™t involve drinking.
Myth:
Â Everyone Drinks
Busted:
Â No they donâ€™t!
Less young people drink alcohol than you would think and remember, it is against the law for anyone under 18 to buy alcohol in a pub, off-licence, supermarket or on-line.
Remember you can talk to FRANK for free and in confidence 24 hours a day on 0300 123 6600.

content.value: You may have heard about heroin in the news recently, find out the facts and what to do in an emergency.
Heroin

Â is a drug made from morphine, which is extracted from the opium poppy. Heroin is a class A drug, so itâ€™s illegal to have for yourself, give away or sell. â€˜Streetâ€™ heroin sold as â€˜brownâ€™ is sometimes now used by clubbers as a chill out drug after a big night out. It is still just the same street heroin but some people mistakenly think itâ€™s not as addictive.Itâ€™s common for heroin to be mixed with a variety of substances, such as sugar, starch, powdered milk, quinine or paracetamol â€“ this increases its weight and the drug dealerâ€™s profits. Take a closer lookÂ
under the microscope
to find out more about heroin purity.
Here are some of the main effects and risks of heroin:
A small dose of heroin gives the user a feeling of warmth and well-being, bigger doses can make you sleepy and very relaxed.
The first dose of heroin can bring about dizziness and vomiting.
Heroin is highly addictive and people can quickly get hooked.

Injecting heroin and sharing injecting equipment can be very risky, as it runs the risk of the injector catching or spreading a virus, such as HIV or hepatitis C. There is also the risk that veins may be damaged and that an abscess or blood clot may develop.
In case of emergency

If someone collapses call an ambulance immediately, turn them onto their side to avoid choking and stay with them until the ambulance arrives. Remember, you wonâ€™t get into trouble with the authorities for having taken drugs â€“ paramedics donâ€™t call the police unless there has been a fatality.

It is still just the same street heroin but some people mistakenly think it's not as addictive.

When the effects of any cocaine start to wear off the crash period sometimes lasts for days afterwards
Possession can get you up to seven years in jail

title.en-US: Avoid the hairy dog: 10 top tips for a Fresherâ€™s week to remember

content.value: Avoid making a â€˜Fresherâ€™s Foolâ€™ of yourself with FRANKS 10 top tips for making your fresherâ€™s week one to remember.
1.Eat!Â
Make sure you stock up on the carbs before going on a big night out. Maybe offer to cook up a big batch of pasta for your new housemates and get to know each other.
2.Be yourself.Â
Changing your opinions or what you wear to fit in with people is exhausting. Donâ€™t be a copy-cat, be yourself and youâ€™ll find friends who respect you for who you are
3.Stick to your guns.Â
Donâ€™t feel under pressure to take drugs if you donâ€™t want to. Say â€˜Noâ€™ firmly but clearly and without making a big deal about it. True friends will accept who you are whatever your response.
4.Student Discount!Â

You might feel like Jordan Belfort when you open your banking app and realise youâ€™ve just been granted the first instalment of your student loan, but it will quickly deteriorate as you go out enjoying yourself. Remember, the majority of high-street chains offer discounts if you flash your student car (just remember to smile in the photo!)
5.Leave the mixing to the DJâ€™s.Â

Be careful about mixing any drugs, including alcohol as this can substantially increase risk of side-effects. If you do take drugs, try to make sure you are with friends and tell them exactly what you have taken in case you run into difficulties, including whether you are mixing your drugs.
6.Legal doesnâ€™t mean Safe.Â

Be wary of so-called â€˜legal highsâ€™, just because a substance is legal, it doesnâ€™t mean it is safe. Legal highs contain a range of potentially dangerous chemicals and their makeup changes all the time - so you can never be certain what you have bought, and what the effects might be.
7.First impressions count.Â
Drinking too much can impair your judgement and leave you feeling like you can dance like Diversity (when it actually looks like your dad). Try to have a glass of water between alcoholic drinks.
8.Pace yourself.Â
You have years at uni to enjoy the nightlife, donâ€™t burnout too early. Enjoy a night in watching trash TV without your parents around to tell you off.
9. Hide an emergency tenner.
Make sure you know how youâ€™re getting home after a night out â€“ check out the university night buses on offer, or save the all-important â€œemergency tennerâ€ to pay for a taxi should you need it.
10. Avoid the hairy dog!Â

Hangover cures like the â€˜hair of the dogâ€™ (drinking more alcohol in the morning) are generally a myth. There are no cures for a hangover. There are only tips for avoiding hangovers and for easing the symptoms if you have one. If you have a big night out, try to drink a pint of water before bed and take a glass of water with you and sip it through the night. Pain killers like paracetamol can ease a headache in the morning.
Remember you can talk to FRANK for free and in confidence 24 hours a day on 0300 123 6600.

The countdown to Christmas officially begins next week - unless youâ€™re a supermarket, in which case youâ€™ve been talking turkey since July. There are lots of Christmas traditions we all love and some we donâ€™t: brussel sprouts; Cliff Richard; Dad dancing.But what is the deal with drinking? You may have heard people chatting at school or watched scenes in your favourite soap. There is lots of information aboutÂ
alcohol
Â out there which can get confusing. FRANK takes a moment to answer some of the big questions about booze.
Is there a safe amount of alcohol that you can drink?Â

For young people â€“ it is recommended that you donâ€™t drink at all if you are under 15, as this can be especially harmful. At age 16 you can drink wine, beer or cider with a meal in a restaurant and the legal age that you can buy alcohol is 18. However, itâ€™s probably best to wait until you are over 18 to drink at all as alcohol is especially harmful when your body is still developing. For adults there are safe limits, 2-3 units for women and 3-4 for men per day however this doesnâ€™t mean that it is safe to drink every day.
Does alcohol make you feel confident?Â

Lots of people think that drinking looks fun and relaxing and will make them feel confident. But there are two sides to it â€“ drinking isnâ€™t all laughs. Although we donâ€™t always talk about it much, drinking can cause all kinds of problems. Although drinking alcohol can make you feel more confident, it can also make you do things you wish you hadnâ€™t - things you canâ€™t undo.
I donâ€™t want to drink but my friends all drink. What should I do?

It is ok not to drink and you should never feel pressurised into doing something you donâ€™t want to do. Less young people drink alcohol than you would think and remember your friends will respect you more for saying how you feel about drinking. Talking to your friends about the reasons you donâ€™t want to drink can help the situation and you may not be the only one who feels this way. Try arranging to meet them to do other things that donâ€™t involve drinking.
Why is mixing drugs and alcohol dangerous?

By mixing drugs you increase the chances of having a bad time. The effects of the drugs might be greatly increased, the drugs might interact in an unexpected way or one drug may stop part of your body working properly which makes the other drug(s) that have been taken more dangerous.

â€˜Speckled Redâ€™ or â€˜Brown Cherriesâ€™ are some of the names for tablets which have been linked to recent deaths in Hungary. When some of the tablets were tested they contained â€˜para-methyl derivative of 4-methylaminorexâ€™. Itâ€™s a bit of a tongue-twister but essentially this substance is thought to be a stimulant, likeÂ
speed
. Stimulants put pressure on the heart and can affect your mind.
A similar drug was withdrawn because of worries that its use led to life-threatening changes on blood pressure.
Whatâ€™s in a name?

â€˜Para-methyl derivative of 4-methylaminorexâ€™ is not really a catchy name so the drug is more likely to be sold under other names. It might be called â€˜Speckled Redâ€™ or â€˜Brown Cherriesâ€™ but these names are just made-up by people who sell drugs. Sometimes, â€˜para-methyl derivative of 4-methylaminorexâ€™ may be found in tablets known by a different brand name.

The names â€˜Speckled Redâ€™ and â€˜Brown Cherriesâ€™ seem to have been used because at least some of those particular tablets were red/brown or red/grey in colour and had a cherry logo stamped on them. The tablets linked to the deaths were pink and green and heart shaped, or were described as â€˜playboy-shapedâ€™ pills.
FRANKâ€™s advice is to remember that you can never be sure whatâ€™s in any tablet or powderâ€¦ whatever its name or whatever it looks like. You can also never be sure how you might react.
If youâ€™re worried about this derivative of 4-methylaminorex or want more information then FRANK is available to chat 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on 0300 123 6600.

title.en-US: Things you might not know about cannabis

content.value: FRANK weeds out the myths from the facts
You may have heard lots of different things aboutÂ
cannabis
Â but what should you believe? FRANK answers some of the most common questions weâ€™re asked about cannabis.
Is cannabis safe because itâ€™s natural?

A big myth about cannabis is that because it is natural it is safe for you to use. Whilst it can make you feel relaxed it can seriously affect your mental health. It can lead to isolation and a lack of motivation, which can result in you not taking part in your hobbies and interests. It can also affect your school work which may lead to poor exam results.
How many people smoke cannabis?
Not as many as you think! In 2012, 89% of 11-15 year olds hadÂ
never
Â tried cannabis.
Is cannabis good for you?

Cannabis or weed can make you feel relaxed and happy but it also has some serious side effects. It can make you feel very anxious and even paranoid. Using it has also been linked, in some people, to serious, long-term mental health problems. Visit the A-Z for more information about theÂ
effects of cannabis
4) Is smoking tobacco better than cannabis?
Smoking anything can cause damage to your lungs whether itâ€™s one joint a week or 10Â
cigarettes

You can talk to them and explain why you are worried about theirÂ

Â use and how it makes you feel. You can point out that there areÂ

title.en-US: Leave the mixing to the DJ

content.value: FRANK explores the risks of mixing drugs and alcohol
The dangers of mixing have been highlighted in the media recently but what are the facts? The truth is that by mixing drugs, includingÂ
alcohol
, you increase the chances of having a bad time for a range of reasons:
Taking similar types of drugs can increase their negative effects.
A drug may impair you in a particular way that makes other drug(s) you take more dangerous than usual.
The drugs might interact in completely unexpected ways.
Mixing heroin and alcohol
Heroin
Â andÂ
alcohol
Â are both depressants which may make you feel relaxed but can slow down your heart rate and breathing which can be fatal. Overdose is much more likely when these drugs are taking together.
Mixing cocaine and alcohol
This combination can produce a poisonous substance in the body that may affect your heart and that stays in your system longer thanÂ
cocaine
Â alone. Mixing cocaine withÂ
alcohol
Â can hide some of the other effects of the drug which makes it easier to overdose as users take more to achieve the same high.
Mixing a stimulant (such as speed) and alcohol
Stimulants likeÂ
speed
Â are substances which make you feel more energetic. Both stimulants andÂ
alcohol
Â put pressure on the heart, particularly with heavy use. Mixing speed with alcohol can therefore increase the risk of heart failure.
If you want to talk to FRANK in confidence then you can call the helpline 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on 0300 123 6600 or you canÂ
chat online
Â between 2-6pm every day.

bodyLegacy.en-US:
**4th October 2013: FRANK explores the risks of mixing drugs and alcohol**

The dangers of mixing have been highlighted in the media recently but what are the facts? The truth is that by mixing drugs, including [alcohol](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/alcohol\"), you increase the chances of having a bad time for a range of reasons:

*   Taking similar types of drugs can increase their negative effects.
*   A drug may impair you in a particular way that makes other drug(s) you take more dangerous than usual.
*   The drugs might interact in completely unexpected ways.

**Mixing heroin and alcohol**  
[Heroin](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/heroin\") and [alcohol](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/alcohol\") are both depressants which may make you feel relaxed but can slow down your heart rate and breathing which can be fatal. Overdose is much more likely when these drugs are taking together.

**Mixing cocaine and alcohol**  
This combination can produce a poisonous substance in the body that may affect your heart and that stays in your system longer than [cocaine](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/cocaine\") alone. Mixing cocaine with [alcohol](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/alcohol\") can hide some of the other effects of the drug which makes it easier to overdose as users take more to achieve the same high.

**Mixing a stimulant (such as speed) and alcohol**  
Stimulants like [speed](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/speed\") are substances which make you feel more energetic. Both stimulants and [alcohol](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/alcohol\") put pressure on the heart, particularly with heavy use. Mixing speed with alcohol can therefore increase the risk of heart failure.

If you want to talk to FRANK in confidence then you can call the helpline 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on 0300 123 6600 or you can [chat online](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/contact-frank\") between 2-6pm every day.

_FRANK News Published: 4th October 2013_

content.value: FRANK's got some handy advice to make sure that your holiday is one to remember for all the right reasons.

Got your exam results? Been working hard in your summer job? Bored of babysitting for your younger brother? Whatever the reason, you may be thinking of letting your hair down and escaping Britain for some summer fun. FRANK loves a holiday so has put together a few tips to make sure you have the best time possible.
Home and away

Itâ€™s easy to get carried away on holiday but remember that there is a dark side to drugs no matter where you are. If something does go wrong youâ€™re a long way from home and different countries have different laws and penalties.Itâ€™s always best to know the facts, otherwise you can never be sure of what youâ€™re getting in to. TheÂ
drugs A-Z

Â is full of information about different drugs but if youâ€™d prefer to talk then you can call on 0300 123 6600 at any time of day throughout the week. Remember if youâ€™re calling from abroad youâ€™ll need to add 44 to the phone number and drop the first 0.
Under pressure

Your mates might be experimenting but you should never feel under pressure to take drugs â€“ being true to yourself is the most important thing. You might be surprised to know that most young people donâ€™t take drugs so donâ€™t feel that itâ€™s something you have to experience.True friends will respect your decision so just say â€˜noâ€™ clearly and firmly. FRANK has got lots more advice onÂ
how to resist peer pressure
Look out for each other

Always keep your friends close. If youâ€™re in an unfamiliar environment with people you donâ€™t know you may get into bad situations more easilyâ€¦.especially if you canâ€™t speak the language! As long as your friends are around, they can advise you and help you.Have fun and keep safe!

content.value: Itâ€™s been in the headlines but what is PMA and how might it affect you?
PMA
Â is similar toÂ
MDMA
Â (the chemical inÂ
ecstasy

). It can make you feel alert, alive and full of energy. Its similarity means that PMA is actually sometimes sold as ecstasy. However, PMA is much stronger, and like MDMA, can cause a fatal rise in body temperature.
Risks

In recent years there have been a number of deaths and hospitalisations that have been linked to PMA and/or PMMA. It appears that those affected thought they were taking ecstasy pills containing MDMA and did not know that the pills contained PMA and/or PMMA. As with any drug you can never be sure what it is your buying and how it might affect you.

As PMA is often sold as ecstasy pills rather than sold by its own name, a lot of the street names associated with PMA are actually street names for ecstasy pills. Sometimes PMA and/or PMMA containing pills even look like regular ecstasy pills.
Youâ€™ll find more information on theÂ
PMA page
Â or you can chat to FRANK on 0300 123 6600 in complete confidence.

title.en-US: Nitrous Oxide, itâ€™s no laughing matter

content.value: Nitrous Oxide
, has been nicknamed â€˜
laughing gas
â€™ due to the euphoric and relaxed feeling people who inhale it can sometimes feel, but itâ€™s not all giggles with this gas.
The gas is normally bought in pressured canisters, commonly transferred to a container, e.g. a balloon, from which the gas is inhaled.
Nitrous oxide is not illegal to possess, but this doesnâ€™t mean that it is safe to use.
The effects of nitrous oxide vary depending on how much has been inhaled but they include:

â€¢ Feelings of euphoria, relaxation and calmness.
â€¢ Dizziness, difficulty in thinking straight and fits of giggles/laughter.
â€¢ Sound distortions or even hallucinations.
â€¢ In some people, a headache can be an unwanted immediate effect.
Risks include:

â€¢ Unconsciousness or death from lack of oxygen. This occurs when the available oxygen for breathing is effectively pushed out by the nitrous oxide.If someone collapses, call an ambulance immediately, turn them onto their side to avoid choking and stay with them until the ambulance arrives. Remember, you wonâ€™t get into trouble with the authorities for having taken drugs â€“ paramedics donâ€™t call the police unless there has been a fatality.

**[Nitrous Oxide](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/nitrous-oxide\")**, has been nicknamed â€˜**laughing gas**â€™ due to the euphoric and relaxed feeling people who inhale it can sometimes feel, but itâ€™s not all giggles with this gas.Â 

  
The gas is normally bought in pressured canisters, commonly transferred to a container, e.g. a balloon, from which the gas is inhaled.  
  
**Nitrous oxide is not illegal to possess, but this doesnâ€™t mean that it is safe to use.**  
  
The effects of nitrous oxide vary depending on how much has been inhaled but they include:  
  
â€¢ Feelings of euphoria, relaxation and calmness.  
â€¢ Dizziness, difficulty in thinking straight and fits of giggles/laughter.  
â€¢ Sound distortions or even hallucinations.  
â€¢ In some people, a headache can be an unwanted immediate effect.  
  
  
**Risks include:**  
  
â€¢ Unconsciousness or death from lack of oxygen. This occurs when the available oxygen for breathing is effectively pushed out by the nitrous oxide.  
  
  
If someone collapses, call an ambulance immediately, turn them onto their side to avoid choking and stay with them until the ambulance arrives. Remember, you won't get into trouble with the authorities for having taken drugs â€“ paramedics don't call the police unless there has been a fatality.

title.en-US: Khat is banned (the drug, not your pet kitty)

content.value: The Government announced today that Khat will become shortly become a Class C drug.

This means that if you are caught with the drug (possession) you could go to prison for two years and get an unlimited fine.If you are caught dealing or supplying (and that could just mean giving some to your mates) you could get 14 years in jail.
It will also be an offence to bring Khat in and/or out of the country, so if youâ€™ve been abroad you cannot bring it back to the UK with you.
But what is Khat?
Khat is a leafy green plant and if you chew its leaves you might feel more alert and talkative. Itâ€™s a stimulant so its effects are similar to amphetamine (
Speed
). Stimulants speed up your mind and body.

Khat can make you feel less hungry and if if itâ€™s chewed over a few hours it can make you feel really calm.However, it can lead to insomnia (which means you canâ€™t go to sleep) and make you confused. It can also make you feel anxious and aggressive.Khat can make your mouth sore and might damage the teeth. There is concern in the long term it might cause mouth cancers.For more information about Khat visit theÂ
Khat A-Z page

**3rd July 2013.** The Government announced today that Khat will become shortly become a Class C drug.

This means that if you are caught with the drug (possession) you could go to prison for two years and get an unlimited fine.

If you are caught dealing or supplying (and that could just mean giving someÂ to your mates) you could get 14 years in jail.

It will also be an offence to bring KhatÂ in and/or out of the country, so if youâ€™ve been abroad you cannot bring it back to the UK with you.

**But what is Khat?**

Khat is a leafy green plant and if you chew its leaves you might feel more alert and talkative. Itâ€™s a stimulant so its effects are similar to amphetamine ([Speed](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/speed\")). Stimulants speed up your mind and body.

Khat can make you feel less hungry and if if it's chewed over a few hours it can make you feel really calm.

However, it can lead to insomnia (which means you canâ€™t go to sleep) and make you confused. It can also make you feel anxious and aggressive.

Khat can make your mouth sore and might damage the teeth. There is concern in the long term it might cause mouth cancers.

For more information about Khat visit the [Khat A-Z page](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/khat\").

content.value: You may have seen Clockwork Orange in the news recently - the smoking blend that is rather than the film!
So what is Clockwork Orange?
Clockwork Orange is a brand name rather than the name of a specific drug. Itâ€™s being sold as a herbal incense smoking blend and likely belongs to a family of drugs called synthetic cannabinoids.
Synthetic cannabinoids
Â are chemicals which act a bit likeÂ
cannabis
Â and are sprayed on to plants which are then smoked. The effects - good and bad - are likely to be very similar to cannabis.
Some users will feel happy and relaxed, may get the giggles, feel hunger pangs and become very talkative.

Others may feel ill or paranoid.As there are lots of different types of cannabinoids and lots of different brands itâ€™s really hard to know what youâ€™re actually smoking and what effect it will have on you.
Update
: Synthetic cannabinoids are now illegal under the psychoactive substances act
You can find out more about synthetic cannabinoids from theÂ
FRANK A-Z entry
Â or by calling the helpline in total confidence on 0300 123 6600.

**22nd April 2013.** You may have seen Clockwork Orange in the news recently - the smoking blend that is rather than the film!

**So what is Clockwork Orange?**  
Clockwork Orange is a brand name rather than the name of a specific drug. Itâ€™s being sold as a herbal incense smoking blend and likely belongs to a family of drugs called synthetic cannabinoids.

[Synthetic cannabinoids](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/Synthetic-cannabinoids\") are chemicals which act a bit like [cannabis](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/cannabis\")Â and are sprayed on to plants which are then smoked. The effects - good and bad - are likely to be very similar to cannabis. Some users will feel happy and relaxed, may get the giggles, feel hunger pangs and become very talkative. Others may feel ill or paranoid.

As there are lots of different types of cannabinoids and lots of different brands itâ€™s really hard to know what youâ€™re actually smoking, what effect it will have on you and whether itâ€™s legal or not.

You can find out more about synthetic cannabinoids from the [FRANK A-Z entry](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/Synthetic-cannabinoids\") or by calling the helpline in total confidence on 0300 123 6600.

_Last updated:_ _22nd April 2013_

title.en-US: 2CB: Random letters and numbers or something more serious?

content.value: What is 2CB?
You may have heard aboutÂ
2CB
, sometimes known asÂ
tripstacy
, in the news this weekend. But what is it? And what effect does it have on you?
2CB is an illegal drug which acts like a cross betweenÂ
ecstasy
Â andÂ
LSD

, producing hallucinations and an energy buzz in many that take it.It can give users feelings of alertness, of being alive and of being in tune with surroundings, like ecstasy, particularly when taken at lower doses. However, it can also lead to headaches and nausea, and at high doses, more serious confused, agitated or even delirious states.
Itâ€™s relatively new in the UK so the long term effects are not yet fully known. However, there have been cases of associated neurological damage and fatal overdose.
2CB is a Class A drug which means that itâ€™s illegal to have for yourself, give away or sell.
For more information and advice, chat to FRANK either by calling 0300 123 6600,Â
sending an email
Â or by text on 82111. Your question is completely confidential.

Annihilationâ€™ is the brand name of a legal herbal smoking mixture, which testing has found contains the chemical MAM2201. This chemical is part a group of drugs known asÂ
synthetic cannabinoids
Synthetic cannabinoids are chemicals that mimic the effects of the main active compound in cannabis, tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).
Synthetic cannabinoids, like cannabis, may make you feel happy, relaxed, give you the giggles or hunger pangs and either more talkative or drowsy.

title.en-US: Keep your cool during Fresherâ€™s Week

content.value: Itâ€™s that time of year where people are heading off to university for the first term. Freshersâ€™ week is famous for being one of the biggest party times of the university term and is where many new friendships are forged. Itâ€™s a lot of fun but itâ€™s easy to get carried away so FRANK has put together a few simple tips to ensure Freshersâ€™ week is a week to remember.
First impressions count
Remember to be yourself and youâ€™ll find friends who respect you for who you are.
Work out where you stand on issues like sex, drugs and alcohol. Knowing your own mind makes it easier to stay true to yourself.

Donâ€™t feel under pressure to take drugs if you donâ€™t want to. Say â€˜Noâ€™ firmly but clearly and without making a big deal about it. If people try to persuade you, donâ€™t feel like you have to change your mind. True friends will accept who you are whatever your response.
Before you hit the town
Try to eat a decent meal before you go out â€“ something high in carbohydrates, such as pasta or a jacket potato will keep you going for longer â€“ and neednâ€™t break the bank!

Make sure you know how youâ€™re getting home â€“ check out the university night buses on offer, or save the all important â€œemergency tennerâ€ to pay for a taxi should you need it. Drugs can impair how you drive so you should never drive if you have been drinking or taking drugs, nor accept a lift from anyone who you know to have been drinking or taken drugs.
During the night

Be wary of taking drinks from large open containers and punch bowls and â€˜mine-sweepingâ€™ (picking up and drinking) unattended drinks â€“ youâ€™ve no way of knowing how strong it is, or even what it is.
Be careful about mixing any drugs, including alcohol as this can substantially increase risk of side-effects.

If you begin to feel drunk or strange after only a few drinks, seek help from a trusted friend or management at the club or pub â€“ in case you are becoming ill, are at risk of an accident or of ending up with people who may not look after you.
If you do take drugs, try to make sure you are with friends and tell them exactly what you have taken in case you run into difficulties, including whether you are mixing your drugs.

Make sure you keep properly hydrated, particularly if you are taking dance drugs like ecstasy. But be careful; too much water consumption can also be dangerous. You should consume no more than a pint of non-alcoholic fluid, such as water, fruit juice or an isotonic drink every hour.
Legal doesnâ€™t mean safe

Be wary of so-called â€˜legal highsâ€™. For example, the legal high 2-DPMP (found in the product Ivory Wave), has recently been associated with a number of hospitalisations. Just because a substance is legal, it doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s safe.
Legal highs contain a range of potentially dangerous chemicals, and their makeup changes all the time - so you can never be certain what you have bought, and what the effects might be.
Remember you can talk to FRANK for free and in confidence 24 hours a day on 0300 123 6600

title.en-US: Get ready for this Summerâ€™s festivals

summary.en-US: Festival season is fast approaching so dig out those wellies, grab your tent.

content.value: Festival season is fast approaching so dig out those wellies, grab your tent and get fully prepared by finding out the facts about drugs from FRANK. Whether you think youâ€™ll take drugs or not, you should know the facts. FRANK has put together a guide to this yearâ€™s summer festivals, to ensure your experience is one to remember â€“ for the right reasons.
Just because theyâ€™re legal doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re safe
Be cautious of â€˜legal highsâ€™, including the drugÂ
2-DPMP
Â (found in the product Ivory Wave) orÂ
Benzo Fury

, that may be available at this yearâ€™s festivals. Just because a substance is legal, it doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s safe.Legal highs contain a range of potentially dangerous chemicals, and their makeup changes all the time - so you can never be certain what you have bought, and what the effects might be.
Leave the mixing to the DJ
Mixing more than one type of drug, including alcohol, on the same night increases your risks and makes the effects more unpredictable. Mixing alcohol and some drugs, likeÂ
GBL

Â (or liquid ecstasy) can cause a coma and death. There are risks whether you mix similar types (e.g. sedative/sedative or stimulant/stimulant) or different types (e.g. stimulant/depressant).Be wary of taking drinks from large open containers and punch bowls and â€˜mine-sweepingâ€™ (picking up and drinking) unattended drinks â€“ youâ€™ve no way of knowing how strong it is, or even what it is.

Donâ€™t do anything you donâ€™t want to do â€“ your mates will respect you more for standing up for yourself.Remember most young people have not experimented with drugs or donâ€™t want to experiment. Youâ€™re not alone!

If someone collapses call an ambulance immediately, turn them onto their side to avoid choking and stay with them until the ambulance arrives.Remember, you wonâ€™t get into trouble with the authorities for having taken drugs â€“ paramedics donâ€™t call the police unless there has been a fatality.FRANK is available on most smartphones and you might find it helpful to link to the section on what to doÂ

bodyLegacy.en-US:
Festival season is fast approaching so dig out those wellies, grab your tent and get fully prepared by finding out the facts about drugs from FRANK.

Whether you think youâ€™ll take drugs or not, you should know the facts. FRANK has put together a guide to this yearâ€™s summer festivals, to ensure your experience is one to remember â€“ for the right reasons.

**Just because theyâ€™re legal doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re safe**  
Be cautious of â€˜legal highsâ€™, including the drug [2-DPMP](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/2-dpmp\") (found in the product Ivory Wave) or [Benzo Fury](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/6-apb#aka=Benzo+Fury\"), that may be available at this yearâ€™s festivals. Just because a substance is legal, it doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s safe.

Legal highs contain a range of potentially dangerous chemicals, and their makeup changes all the time - so you can never be certain what you have bought, and what the effects might be.

**Leave the mixing to the DJ**  
Mixing more than one type of drug, including alcohol, on the same night increases your risks and makes the effects more unpredictable. Mixing alcohol and some drugs, like [GBL](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/drug/ghb#aka=GBL\") (or liquid ecstasy) can cause a coma and death. There are risks whether you mix similar types (e.g. sedative/sedative or stimulant/stimulant) or different types (e.g. stimulant/depressant).

Be wary of taking drinks from large open containers and punch bowls and â€˜mine-sweepingâ€™ (picking up and drinking) unattended drinks â€“ youâ€™ve no way of knowing how strong it is, or even what it is.

**Under pressure**  
Work out where you stand on issues like sex, drugs and alcohol. Knowing your own mind makes it easier to stay true to yourself. Donâ€™t do anything you donâ€™t want to do â€“ your mates will respect you more for standing up for yourself.

Remember most young people have not experimented with drugs or donâ€™t want to experiment. Youâ€™re not alone!

**Keep your friends close**  
Itâ€™s a good idea to stick together with your mates at festivals. If you do take something, then tell your friends what youâ€™ve taken â€“ if something does go wrong then youâ€™ll need their help.

If someone starts to get stressed, take them somewhere quiet, try to calm them down and send for help if needed.Â 

**In case of emergencyâ€¦**  
If someone collapses call an ambulance immediately, turn them onto their side to avoid choking and stay with them until the ambulance arrives.

Remember, you won't get into trouble with the authorities for having taken drugs â€“ paramedics don't call the police unless there has been a fatality.

FRANK is available on most smartphones and you might find it helpful to link to the section on what to do [if someone has a bad time](\"http://www.talktofrank.com/emergency-help\"), including collapsing and putting someone into the recovery position.

Updated: 21st June 2012

content.value: If you're with someone who needs medical help, call an ambulance and tell the crew everything you know about the drugs taken, it could save their life. If you have any drugs left, hand them over to the crew as it may help.
They won't tell the police

Most people donâ€™t use drugs and even among those that do, emergencies are rare.Â But no one can be certain how drugs will affect them so thereâ€™s always the risk theyâ€™ll have a bad time, fall ill, hurt themselves or even worse.
Should you ever need to help someone whoâ€™s having a bad reaction, hereâ€™s what you need to know:
What to look out for
If someone is having a bad time on drugs they may be:
anxious
tense
panicky
overheated and dehydrated
drowsy
having difficulty with breathing
What to do
TheÂ
first things
you
Â should do are:
stay calm
calm them and be reassuring - donâ€™t scare them or chase after them
try to find out what theyâ€™ve taken
stay with them
IfÂ they are
anxious, tense or panicky
Â you should:
sit them in a quiet and calm room
keep them away from crowds, bright lights and loud noises
tell them to take slow deep breaths
stay with them
IfÂ they are
really drowsy
Â you should:
sit them in a quiet place and keep them awake
if they donâ€™t respond or become unconscious call an ambulance immediately and place them in the recovery position
donâ€™t scare them, shout at them or shock them
donâ€™t give them coffee to wake them up
donâ€™t put them in a cold bath to â€œwake them upâ€ â€“ this wastes time and thereâ€™s a risk of drowning
IfÂ they are
unconsciousÂ or having difficulty breathing
you should:
Immediately phone for an ambulance
Place them into the recovery position
Stay with them until the ambulance arrives
If you know what drug theyâ€™ve taken tell the ambulance crew immediately, it might them get the right treatment faster
Recovery position

By placing someone in the recovery position, youâ€™re making sure that they are still breathing and can breathe easily, as itâ€™s not unusual for someone who has become unconscious to swallow their tongue. Youâ€™re also making sure that if they vomit,  it wonâ€™t block their airway and choke them.
Open their airway by tilting the head and lifting their chin. Lie them on their side and straighten their legs.

Â Place the arm nearest to you at right angles to the body. Get hold of the far leg just above the knee and pull it up, keeping the foot flat on the ground. Place their other hand against their cheek.
Â Keep their hand pressed against their cheek and pull on the upper leg to roll them towards you and onto their side.
Â Tilt the head back so they can breathe easily.
Â Make sure that both the hip and the knee of the upper leg are bent at right angles.
What happens in A&E
In A&E the doctors and nurses will treat your friend as best as they can. This may involve giving an antidote or treatment to counteract the effect of the drugs.

You can help by telling the ambulance crew, the doctors and nurses all you know about what drug(s) your friend had taken, if theyâ€™d been drinking, and if your friend has any medical conditions and if there are still some of the drugs left, hand them over.

Providing this information will help them give your friend the right treatment without delay. They wonâ€™t tell the police, your friendâ€™s family or others not involved in their clinical care, that your friend has been taking drugs.
Did you know?
999 is the number for the emergency services in the UK, but you can also call 112 for help
112 is the single emergency telephone number for anywhere in Europe
NaloxoneÂ

Naloxone is an emergency antidote to opiate overdose. It counteracts the effects of opioid drugs (such as heroin, methadone and fentanyl) and reverses the life-threatening effects of an overdose on breathing.
Local services can make naloxone available, alongside training on how to use it, so that it can be supplied to people who might need it, such as drug users, their family and friends.
If you think someone has overdosed, you need to call an ambulance straight away so that expert help is immediately on its way.
Itâ€™s normally very easy for people to use naloxone if theyâ€™ve had simple training. Overdose and naloxone training normally provides advice on:
how to recognise a possible opioid overdose
how to check for depressed or absent breathing
how to put the person in the recovery position (see diagram above) and call for an ambulance
how to use the naloxone product(s) available locally
It is possible to give too much naloxone too quickly, so any training should give clear advice about building up the dose in stages as needed.

If it looks like the person is not breathing at all, or their heart has stopped, they will need further first aid before the ambulance arrives. The affected person will probably need mouth to mouth resuscitation and chest compressions (CPR). They might still benefit from a naloxone injection, but this mustnâ€™t delay starting the required CPR.
Most overdose situations will need the ambulance to be called, the person put in the recovery position (see above or this
NHS guide
), naloxone injected, and someone to stay with the affected person until professional help arrives.

Naloxone works to reverse opioid overdose for only a short period of time. Even when the naloxone does work first time, you will still need to keep an eye on the person until the ambulance arrives, and during this time you may need to top up the naloxone more than once to keep the person awake and breathing adequately. An ambulance should always be called andÂ
someone should stay with the person until the ambulance arrives.
For more information about first aid, see the NHS Choices First Aid web pageÂ

intro.en-US:
If you're feeling pressure to take drugs, here's how to deal with it

Youâ€™re not alone! Itâ€™s easy to think youâ€™re the only one who has not experimented with drugs. The reality is that most people your age donâ€™t take drugs and youâ€™re in the majority.

content.value: Work out where you stand on issues like sex, drugs and alcohol. Knowing your own mind makes it easier to stay true to yourself.
Prepare yourself now by thinking through how you want to respond and behave.Â  It may help to share your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust.
Try to understand who is offering you the drugs and why â€“ friends should understand if you say no, people you donâ€™t know very well may expect something in return.
Say no firmly but clearly and without making a big deal about it. If they try to persuade you, donâ€™t feel like you have to change your mind.
They may not show it, but your mates will respect you more if youâ€™re assertive and clear about what you do and donâ€™t want to do.

Take a look around â€“ it might not seem like it, but youâ€™re not the only one worrying about what other people think of you. Try to focus on your own opinion of yourself â€“ in the end, thatâ€™s all that matters.
Watch out for your mates -Â if youâ€™re worried about a friend, donâ€™t keep it to yourself. Talk to them, or someone you trust.
If youâ€™re finding it hard to be yourself within your group, take a step back, and think about whether itâ€™s time to find a new crowd to hang out with.
Before trying anything new it makes sense to get the facts straight.Â Â For friendly and confidential advice, talk to FRANK on 0300 123 6600Â at any time of the day or night.

intro.en-US: You probably canâ€™t stop your child from coming into some contact with drugs, but by staying as informed as possible, you can help them make the right choices when they do.

content.value: Step 1: You notice somethingâ€™s wrong

You may have realised that youâ€™re not in full control of your drug use and that itâ€™s causing problems. These problems might involve money, strained friendships, broken relationships, your job, or getting arrested.Â
If youâ€™re developing a problem with prescribed or over-the-counter medicines, you may find youâ€™ve been hiding the amount youâ€™re taking or lying about your symptoms.Â
Step 2: You go to get expert help
There are two main ways you can find treatment:Â
Through your GP
Your GP makes a referral for you to a treatment service
Self-referral

Details of treatment services are available online, from your local NHS services and in the phone book. If you want details of treatment services, FRANK has a directory of treatment services, or you can call the FRANK helpline and talk confidentially to one of our advisors.
Step 3: Youâ€™re assessed

Before treatment can start, youâ€™ll need to discuss your drug use with a doctor, other health professionals or a trained substance misuse worker. They will let you know what treatment options are available for your drug use and any other health problems you may have. Your personal care plan will then be developed with you. This care plan normally details your immediate and longer-term treatment goals and is intended to be updated throughout your time in treatment as your needs and circumstances change.
Step 4: Treatment is discussed with you

Your treatment journey should be tailored to your circumstances and needs, but most treatment does involve some form of talking therapy. Prescribed medication is also needed for certain drug problems. See below for more information on different types of treatment.
Step 5: You change your lifestyle

Recovery from a drug problem often involves a long-term lifestyle change, and a number of social factors can help you not to use drugs (called abstinence) and can help you to achieve an improved quality of life.Â

These include having stable accommodation, developing a new network of non-drug using friends, re-engaging in education or work, and support from others who have had the similar problems. Mutual aid groups, like Narcotics Anonymous or Cocaine Anonymous, can play an important role in this for many people, as can new forms of peer support, like Smart Recovery groups.

content.value: It might seem OK to buy some drugs or medicines online because they come in medical packaging or are sold by an internet pharmacy, but there are some big risks if you buy online. Online pharmacies that are registered to sell in the UK are OK but others may not be. You should look for these registered pharmacy and verification logos*, and you can check whether online pharmacies or any other online healthcare services, including online doctors, areÂ
registered
Â orÂ
here
Â before using them.

Medicine bought from other sites might be fake but disguised as authentic medicines. The package might not contain the drug or the dose that it says it does. And each pill might contain much more of the active ingredient than it is supposed to or it might contain ingredients that are bad quality or poisonous. If they have not been properly checked they can pose a real risk to your health. For example, you might get something thatâ€™s been made to look like Xanax but which doesnâ€™t actually contain any alprazolam (the active ingredient in Xanax) or with such a high dose of alprazolam that you could end up in hospital.

Ordering from these dodgy websites also puts your personal and financial information at risk. It might be collected and sold on to a criminal and used to take money from you or someone else. As for the legal position, buying online is no different to buying in person. Receiving an order from an overseas website would be treated in the same way as importing, which could carry a long prison sentence.

bodyLegacy.en-US:
